comment.author: 38003584@N08
comment._content: This is an amazing piece of Sydney's history. I didn't know we had ever had an outbreak of plague.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mariafranklin] There were 12 major plague outbreaks in Australia between 1900 and 1925. Official government statistics record 1371 cases resulting in 535 deaths. The 1900 outbreak in Sydney is the most widely known, mainly due to the remarkable photographic work of John Degotardi, Jr. See also State Records' Purging Pestilence – Plague! Gallery - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/index.php/galleries/purging-pe...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Sorry to be another kind of persistent pest,  but does anyone know EXACTLY where this "Johnstone's lane" is, or was?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes, there is a Johnston [sic] Lane in Annandale, whizz-up-and-downable in GoogleStreetView.  Matching view not yet found,  unfortunately.  The houses on the left look relatively OK,  and may still survive.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Just came across this zoomable 1903 map showing plague infection areas - red for 1900, blue for 1902. Click on the third map down at www.baseline.nsw.gov.au/exhibitions/maps/infrastructure.html .
